Playing on Centre Court at Wimbledon is a unique experience because of the silence. When you play, you can hear the sound of the ball on the soft grass and the echo of each shot. The well-kept grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds make you feel separated from the outside world. This quiet helps me focus on my game. During a match, I try to concentrate only on the game and the point I am playing. The silence is only broken by the noise of applause and cheers when a point is won. Even though there are fifteen thousand people watching, I feel like they are far away. I am so focused that I forget millions are watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final, the biggest match of my life.

I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, who has been my coach all my life, taught me that this is the most important tournament. By the time I was 14, I was telling my friends that I would play there one day and win. Before 2008, I had played and lost twice against Federer, including in the final the year before. Losing in 2006 was not too hard because I was just happy to have made it that far at twenty years old. Federer beat me easily because I didn’t believe in myself enough. But losing in 2007 was very hard. I knew I could have done better, and it was my mindset, not my skills, that let me down. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that loss. Losing is always painful, but it is worse when you know you had a chance to win. Toni, who is a very tough coach, usually criticizes me even when I win. But after that loss, he tried to comfort me, saying there would be more chances to win Wimbledon. I told him he didn’t understand, and I thought it was my last chance. I know a professional athlete’s career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Some moments are more important than others, and I felt I missed a big one in 2007. Toni couldn’t make me feel better, but he was right in the end. I got another chance in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I had learned from my defeat and that my mindset would be strong this time. The night before the final, I had dinner with family and friends, and we didn’t talk about the match. They knew I was already thinking about the game in my mind, and I needed that space to be mine alone until the match started.

In April 1957, a young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa. She wrote home saying she was living in the Africa she had always dreamed of. Jane spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society made her famous with articles and TV shows about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including children's books and the bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages.

Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, possibly second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes hides her real achievements. Many stories about her life focus on her adventurous spirit and dreams of living with wild animals, but these stories can overlook her true contributions. Based on her research, the success of her students, and the data she collected over 40 years, Jane Goodall should be seen as a leading pioneer in her field and a top zoologist. Her main achievement is that she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees.

Before Goodall's work, people misunderstood chimpanzees. They didn't know chimpanzees ate meat or used tools. They also didn't realize chimpanzees have emotions and social systems similar to humans. Goodall's book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," is a key work in chimpanzee research. Her study in Gombe, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements by biologist Stephen Jay Gould. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves, as chimpanzees are our closest relatives.

Even as a child, Jane showed signs of her future career. At five years old, she disappeared one day, causing a search by police and neighbors. She reappeared with straw in her hair, explaining she had hidden in a henhouse for five hours to see how hens lay eggs. This curiosity foreshadowed her future as a biologist.

During our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using different voices: a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children’s TV and cartoons, and to those who have seen computer programs about health and safety. ‘I’ve just done a voiceover about back injuries,’ she says, ‘so I had to quickly learn how to say many medical terms.’ Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. ‘Many actors, even famous ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,’ she says. ‘But there’s more to it. You have to make the script come alive for an audience who can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions for publicity, but often they don’t get the parts because they’re used to acting with their whole bodies.’ After school, Shirley took a drama course, planning a regular acting career. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV ads. ‘One day,’ she says, ‘the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, amazingly, got a major part.’ Shirley realized she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. ‘Things just happened for me,’ she says. ‘In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character – and her brother and mother.’ Adult female actors often provide voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex procedures and lots of paperwork, which production companies on tight schedules prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the highlight of a job that includes everything from educational videos to vacuum cleaner ads. ‘Those are hard because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this profession help,’ she says. ‘They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you're talking – that makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a big difference.’ The competition for work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording showing what the artist can do – is essential. ‘It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,’ Shirley says. ‘There are agencies that specialize in helping voiceover artists create them.’ She claims to have reached the top of her profession through persistence as much as natural talent. ‘Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or simply practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.’ For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending ‘specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.’ She also believes a passion for human sound is important, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she performs. ‘If I’ve been in the studio doing a particular kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,’ she says. ‘My children have grown up used to their mum talking in completely different voices.’

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a dream job for many kids, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually choose more practical careers, like becoming a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea of making a living by drawing doodles, like those in school notebooks, seems silly. But some people do it. 

People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. In my case, I loved comic strips as a child, contributed to school publications, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper looking for political cartoons on local issues. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and soon I was making enough money to support myself.

To become a cartoonist, you don't need a university degree, much money, or even great drawing skills. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical skills needed are basic, but the job is still tough. You shouldn't try to become a cartoonist unless you feel you can't do anything else. It's easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and leaves time for family and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I've done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I've also been a writer, caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don't turn down any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don't really want to do. It helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with newspapers and magazines. But those days are mostly over. Today, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to create and sell your work. Cartoonists with average talent but good business skills often do better than artistic geniuses who lack those skills.

It's surprising how many people are afraid someone will steal their ideas, even if they've never sold a cartoon. Some are so worried they won't show their work to anyone. Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small 'c' for 'copyright,' put a circle around it, and write your name and the date. But honestly, it's more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it goes viral online, it might actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and decided to get rid of some things. One of those things was an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate throwing things away, so why did I want to get rid of it? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to throw it away when a young man came up to me, looking confused. He asked, "You're not just going to throw that away, are you?" I said I was, but I already felt a bit of regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. We went our separate ways, but I felt sad about it for years.

Then, a few months ago, I got an email that changed everything. It reminded me of a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish at a restaurant. The email was from a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He said, "I’ve got your electric guitar." The guitar had been bought and sold several times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back and used it to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was so emotional. I would have paid anything, but his price was fair. I had forgotten my dad's habit of putting name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this story!

My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar in the 1970s when it was popular. I loved its calming sound, but I didn’t make much progress. So, I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple music. It was also the time of punk music, where you didn’t need to play well to be a rock star. When I got my guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again, it felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I felt the need to stand up and play it with a strap over my shoulder. My fingers remembered the chords, even though I couldn’t draw them. My fingertips felt the pain of pressing the strings. The electric guitar isn’t really for playing alone, so I might need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe I’ll find others my age with similar stories. We could call ourselves ‘The Regainers’!

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," about people who can't sleep well, I felt like I was the only one talking about how dangerous it is to not get enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and moods. People who have trouble sleeping know how important sleep is for our mental, physical, and social health. It's good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. But what about dreams? I haven't heard much about them in these discussions. We often lose dreams when we wake up early, missing the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM or 'Rapid Eye Movement' sleep, the stage with the most dreams. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen during REM, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM, so someone who lives 90 years will spend six or seven years dreaming. When researchers stop people from having REM sleep, they have more intense REM sleep the next night to make up for it. This suggests that dreams are important. When REM was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who thought that understanding dreams was key to understanding our minds. But later research didn't support this idea, and the study of dreams shifted to their physical origins. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, says Robert Stickgold, a sleep scientist at Harvard University. Dreams matter. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than other people. He concluded that using dreams increases with interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Doesn't everyone, like teachers, software designers, and politicians, need to think creatively? Dreams, according to Stickgold, help us connect things in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to find new ideas. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken up from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They ignore the obvious and make unexpected connections, which is what creativity is, says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, even one you barely remember, seems to help with thinking. On those days, words and images come so quickly that I can hardly keep up. I don't know how it works, but it does. But creativity isn't just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and we all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England. In her studio, which has a beautiful sea view, you see empty frames on the walls and photos of her two daughters. Susie is a leading artist in the copyist art movement, known for her ability to recreate the richness of early-20th century impressionist paintings and the brilliance of 16th-century Caravaggio portraits. Surprisingly, she doesn't keep any of her own work. 'As soon as I finish them, they go,' she says. Susie is in high demand. Over her 30-year career as a copyist artist, she has painted works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that even art experts can mistake them for the originals. While the originals sell for millions, her copies sell for between a few hundred pounds and £12,000, depending on the time she spends on them. Susie doesn't usually reveal her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors are true art lovers, but for others, status is important. One celebrity likes to show off his 'Van Gogh' painting, which is actually a 'Susie Ray Van Gogh.' 'Many famous people pretend my copies are originals,' she says. 'That's their choice.' Some collectors save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank and displaying Susie's copy. Susie is honest about her work. She makes her reproductions look as authentic as possible because she believes doing a poor job would disrespect the original artist. She signs her name on the back of the canvas. Selling a copy as an original is illegal, and although she knows people who have done it, she has never been tempted. People who make fakes often get into trouble. Susie isn't rich and has had tough times, but her situation is more stable now, and risking her reputation doesn't make sense. Susie wasn't always a copyist. After her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, earning very little. It was good training for her current work and gave her a love for plants, but it was hard to live on. She had to be very precise and get things right the first time. She has no regrets but is glad she found something more financially rewarding. When young artists ask for advice, Susie tells them to learn to draw accurately. She also emphasizes the importance of studying to do what she does. Her skills allow her to do anything from drawing plants to copying 15th-century masterpieces to reproducing 20th-century abstract art. She now focuses on French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. Susie says people often think modern art is easy, almost like child's play. Impressionists painted quickly and freely, but they were also very detailed, which is hard to achieve. Given her talent, it's surprising Susie doesn't create her own original art. Isn't art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She says her work is the result of years of training and practice, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried creating her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—good, but not special. Susie is a perfectionist.

During her racing career, Ellen MacArthur was passionate about the sea and being the fastest sailor. From a young age, she was obsessed with sailing. She felt a special connection with the boats she sailed around the world. On land, she found everyday life unimportant and was eager to return to the ocean, even though it was dangerous. After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo round-the-world race, she showed me her small boat, Kingfisher, where she lived and worked for 94 days. She explained how she carefully planned everything, even the number of kitchen paper rolls she needed. Preparation was crucial for her. She proudly showed her supplies of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and medical necessities. Her boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, an island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey. Seeing abandoned whaling stations made her realize how humans take resources and move on. When I visited her office, she explained why we must act now to save the planet. She said, "No one is making coal, oil, or gas anymore. They are precious resources we have only once. We need to find a way not to use them up." Initially, her message was to use less, but she now focuses on re-using, like reusable industrial carpet tiles.

For the past three years, Ellen has visited factories, mines, and power stations, talking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. She admits she's not an expert but loves learning. She feels that sailing now seems selfish compared to her new mission, which is about using her voice to make a difference. She started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and education to inspire young people to create a sustainable future. Ellen misses the adventure of being at sea, where she felt connected and focused on survival. However, she believes her new mission is more important than anything she has done before.

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous among teenagers. Many young people spend a lot of time on computers and video games, so Jordan hopes to encourage them to go outside and try new challenges. His climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero.' Climbing Everest is just one of their goals. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he turns 20.

I talked to some experienced Everest climbers, and none of them thought it was a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb the world's highest mountain. They agreed that a young climber might be physically strong enough, but they were unsure if a teenager would be emotionally ready. They also doubted that a young person could have enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing. The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, ‘I know people criticize us, but I can't focus on that – we have a lot to do. We think about the risks, but we trust our experience as climbers. Watching Jordan grow stronger gives me confidence.’

I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it because his father loves adventure? Paul says, ‘This isn't about me wanting fame through my son. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later, but we decided, why not now? We always check with him to make sure he still wants to do it.’ When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, ‘I just focus on reaching my goal.’

In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record attempt. The more exciting the record, the more people are interested. This creates a challenge for Jordan. People might say that focusing on records takes away from the fun, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he needs to be in the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. Paul says, ‘If Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we'll stop this project and go to the gym.’

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's likely they aren't listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won't know who he is. I'm studying music at university, but even my classmates don't know much about classical music. If you don't know the composers, you probably don't own their music. This is sad for classical music fans. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical album sells only 300 copies. I find this hard to believe. Why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries? Older people blame TV and video games, but I don't think that's the reason. The truth is, classical music doesn't attract most people, especially teenagers, who buy the most music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who love classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I'm not a big classical music fan. I like many music styles, but my classical music collection is probably close to that 3% figure. So why don't teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its mood changes, are difficult for us. We like to talk, play, and think fast. Experts say we can't focus for more than three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for a pop song. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop music topics are more interesting to us than long classical pieces without lyrics. Classical music is powerful but doesn't deal with issues that matter to teenagers. How we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families played music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music online, but we rarely listen to classical music. When was the last time you heard classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says more people are going to classical concerts now, but I doubt many are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don't know why people like classical concerts more as they get older, but I know that if your parents love something, teenagers often avoid it. Some say schools are to blame for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids are excited to play in their school orchestra. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They like classical music when they perform, but it's not their first choice when they relax. They separate the two activities. When we want to relax, we choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you regret I came here," she said to the school, smiling. Her mother was getting out of the car too, but she didn’t hear Bonnie. Bonnie didn’t mind if her mother heard because she already knew how Bonnie felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among trees on a hillside; it was confusing at first. Then she saw signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," Bonnie said, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," her mother said. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog," said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be kicked out soon anyway," she thought to herself, "so why not start now?" She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was an old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. They were well cared for, she could see that right away. Almost every stall had a horse, and she walked along, looking at each one. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony, touching its nose. The next horse surprised her. "You’re the best one here!" she said. He was brown with some white. He seemed lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," Bonnie said, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to win a big competition…" His name was Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle for you. They must be nearby." The room with the riding equipment was unlocked, which made Bonnie happy. She was so focused on putting a saddle on Maverick that she forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said, "and I’m serious because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else." She made him walk, then trot. "If I stay here, I think we could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The movement was exciting, and the breeze made her cheeks glow. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he would jump well.

I’ve met Cody Simpson before and have always been impressed by how calmly confident he is. Cody is a 15-year-old from Australia who has already released many successful songs. So, how did a relaxed surfer end up performing in front of thousands of fans? Cody explains, "I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven." But back then, he was more focused on swimming and surfing. He was 13, attending high school, and then he posted a few videos online. These videos changed everything. He started by posting a video of him and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans commented online, asking for more videos. So, Cody, who had recorded more at home, was happy to share them. The response was huge. Cody was also a talented swimmer, training with top coaches and focusing on his sport. But then record labels showed interest, and he had a tough decision: stay in Australia and keep swimming, or take a big risk by signing a music deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the risk. "It was very hard for me, especially at such a young age, to choose a career," he says. "Can you imagine, at 12 or 13, trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?" He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. "It was a big surprise to most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid," he says, remembering their shocked reactions. "I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to be that way in this crazy world." So Cody packed his bags and moved with his family to the US, giving up one dream to try to make another come true. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and isn’t directly involved in his career, they support him from the background. Cody says it’s important to have a close group of great people around you to keep you grounded. Of course, everyone has days of doubt. "Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight, traveling the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a regular life," Cody admits. "I worry about that sometimes, but my family always reassures me that they’re here to support and encourage me." Success, in any career, comes from being willing to say "yes" to your big opportunity, even when it’s a bit scary. "It all happened so fast and unexpectedly," Cody says. "Now, to be visiting countries I never thought I’d see and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s like something many people dream of and try to achieve. But I know it won’t last forever."

I jumped out of bed, pulled back the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbag wall, which was there to stop the buildings from flooding when the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting those sandbags. Last week, I worked with most of the town's adults for long hours to show I could do it. But my grandfather didn't seem to notice. With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile stretch of steaming black water from the wood factory in Milltown. There was fragile ice on both sides, and solid ice downstream. As I changed out of my pyjamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn't know him. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for the lucky silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. It's better than having a famous grandfather because only he, my mom, and I know about it. Plus, I have his diary from that trip. I keep it under my pillow and read it before I sleep. I patted the chain and went to the kitchen. ‘Morning, Rex,’ Mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into Grandpa as he came out of his room. ‘Watch where you’re going!’ he shouted. ‘Where are you going?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ My wetsuit should have made that clear. He sees me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it's getting harder. ‘Why train? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. His words hurt, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He went into the bathroom and slammed the door. Mom gave me a sympathetic smile. ‘Don’t mind him. He’s…’ ‘…not himself right now,’ I finished for her. I didn’t say he’s always been like that. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a kid, he was my hero, especially when he showed me his photos in National Geographic. Those old photos still hang on his bedroom wall, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at and, maybe soon, my own face in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, this grumpy old man. Mom smiled. ‘At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination, even on cold days!’ I smiled back as I peeled my banana. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. ‘If I find sponsors for my expedition.’ She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. I hurried to the boathouse in the backyard.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unfinished painting by Grandpa. It was different from his usual work. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. It showed a river, but not one she recognized. It might not even be a real river, just an imaginary one. The picture was strange and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely noticeable, just a hint of green. The eye was drawn to the pale waters leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, Jess was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." Her voice sounded too casual, hiding her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others interpret them. Mum turned the picture over and showed Jess the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud: "River Boy." The words felt important to her, but she didn't know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it? For him to be so specific. Maybe he'll add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual picture, especially with a name. You can guess his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem. We either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to everyone." "Ignoramus, he said." "… every ignoramus what it means. If artists had to explain their pictures to everyone, they'd never get any work done. And he said …" Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I hoped you might know something about this painting since you seem to be a sort of muse for him." "Muse?" "Someone who inspires an artist." Jess knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint. He'd say the muse wasn't being kind to him or that he needed to be nice to the muse for a difficult part. He never suggested the muse was her. She thought he meant a goddess, not a person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have accidentally cut the carpet. I'm not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn't wake up thinking, "Today I will cut a hole in my carpet." It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm unlucky that way.

What I was really trying to do was find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's very cute, small, painted white with pink and blue flowers, and has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and milkmaids. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I always loved her cabinet, so I was excited when she gave it to me! But it's a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle, so it needs to stand in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it's the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the tiny one, like a broom cupboard, is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. And when Tom goes to University, I can choose. But since Angela is only fifteen, I'll be in my small room for a while. I don't mind; I like my little bedroom. It's cosy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried fitting Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. If I could only cut a couple of centimetres off the bottom of it... Then I had an idea. If I couldn't cut the cabinet, maybe I could cut a hole in the carpet. It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to "think outside the box." And that's exactly what I was doing!

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in a house. They secretly take things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how it should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' point of view, not the humans', which made filming more complicated. The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when filming them, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. To show the Borrowers' view of the human world, the crew had to film from no higher than 15 centimeters off the ground, which wore out a lot of jeans! We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. A big challenge was making the shadows look right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We created a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous US director George Lucas called to ask how we did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully surreal. When I asked them to carry giant things like scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh. In the story, there's a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was so scary they didn't have to act. Getting the costumes right was important to me, and other directors have struggled with this in other versions. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls' clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn't sit during breaks and had to be sewn into the dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material would look too smooth. Unfortunately, it was really hot during filming, and I don't think they thanked me for the detailed costumes! Most scenes away from the Borrowers' home were filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen. It was hard for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how they should look – I did 2,000 by the end. They weren't accurate, but they worked. The budget didn't allow for special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly – I once filmed a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists, but there are none. I wonder how long it will take before the chaos starts. It always does. The fake smiles, the people pretending to be friends, and the requests for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. "Everything’s going to be fine," I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me to face this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to leave my old life of traveling and tutors. While the rest of the band is here for recording, we’re staying permanently. I chose this school because I want to meet real kids. Maybe a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns. That would be so normal. 

I walk into the school’s main office. "Hi, I need my schedule, please," I say to the school secretary. "Name?" she asks, not very friendly. "Desert McGraw." "Desirée?" she asks, leaning closer. "Desert," I repeat. She seems confused. "Oh," she says and types "McGraw" on her keyboard. That’s one good thing. Few people recognize my last name because my dad uses his stage name. "What grade?" "Eleventh." "One second, it’s printing," she says. She hands me the schedule. English Literature is my first class. Great, I like English. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look lost. When I reach the door, the teacher is already calling roll. "Aurelio Gonzalez." "Here." I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! No one will suspect anything now! "Nice shoes," she whispers. I look at my expensive shoes with embroidered flowers. Oh no, I knew I shouldn’t have worn these. "Thanks," I say. The teacher pauses. "Desert... McGraw?" she says. "Here." The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us about the books we need to read, she gives us time to talk! All teachers should do this. "So why’d you move here?" my new friend asks. I have many options. Do I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? "We need a change, Desert," he said, "and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed." Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else choose a studio near the sand? "My dad had to relocate," I tell her. Yes, lies work better. "What does he do?" she asks. Oh well, everyone will find out eventually. But I’ll pretend to be normal until then. "He’s an artist," I say, playing with my backpack zipper. "Cool. I’m Becca, by the way." And she doesn’t seem to care. Perfect.

The average American teenage girl today is expected to do many things. She should be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in all these areas. This is what being a teenager in America is like now. Teenage boys and girls can't just go to school and be average. Being average is not enough anymore. If you don't have big goals, people might think you are lazy. 

Teenager Kristen Loose says, "People, especially adults, forget how much pressure teenagers have these days. We have lots of homework, tests, activities outside of school, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home. Plus, we try to have a social life." Even though these pressures are normal for teenagers today, negative stereotypes about them still exist. The media often shows teenagers as lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers might be like this, it's not fair to say all teenagers are the same.

Loose says, "Many people think we spend most of our time watching TV or on our phones." She believes this is not true. She admits she keeps her phone close most of the time, but not just for fun. It's a tool that helps teenagers and their families. People expect students to have access to the world and be reachable all the time, which can look like a phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their work anywhere. They might listen to language lessons instead of music on the way to school. Schoolwork and activities now need attention all the time, adding to teenagers' busy lives.

Many teenagers start their day at 6 or 7 a.m. and finish after midnight. Their day is full of school, activities, family duties, and homework. Then, they have to do it all again the next day, often with less than the recommended nine hours of sleep. The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20% of teens get nine hours of sleep a night. Also, 28% of teens said they fall asleep in school at least once a week because they are so tired.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says she has about 18 hours of free time a week after all her activities. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. Olsen doesn't waste this time on social media or TV. She spends a lot of it volunteering. "People think teenagers only care about themselves and their own interests," Olsen says. But she loves volunteering and making a positive impact in her school and community. 

In 20 years, we don't know what people will think about teenagers, but they will likely still be proving stereotypes wrong and making the world better. There will be a new generation of students who are making big changes, even before they finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US, near the Sierra Nevada mountains. Over the past few years, this group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a science project with a twist: it's part astronomy experiment, part adventure, which attracts teenagers. I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal piece from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside was a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer to check temperature changes. Two GPS trackers were on the outside to help find it later. A gas tank, donated by someone from a nearby state, was used to inflate the balloon, which grew to the size of a small car. An older boy had driven seven hours to get the gas. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he said. For kids in this club, that's normal. Finally, it was time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they chanted, and the balloon started to rise. Some of them ran and tracked its path with powerful flashlights, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There was a quiet sense of wonder. Then the balloon disappeared into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside and looked at the clear sky, hard to believe it was just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city of about 4 million people. I watched a boy get into a sleeping bag and fall asleep. ‘We're the only ones talking,’ said one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispered another. A meteor shot across the sky. As the balloon rose, the air pressure decreased, and the balloon expanded until it was almost the size of a house. Then it burst in a dramatic explosion. A parachute helped the equipment inside the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students would find it the next day, using the GPS trackers. Getting it back wasn’t easy, but that was part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box almost always lands in the middle of nowhere. ‘To me, recoveries are a huge part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, who noted they've lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey has been becoming more familiar with this landscape in a way you never normally would.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but to get it, the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. Then they had to decide whether to drive or walk – it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or a tall tree. ‘It's important to remember that these students are from the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader said. ‘What may seem wild and dangerous to some is just a way of life to others.’ In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, high on a flat rock, in the middle of a waterfall. The camera hadn't recorded any shooting stars. Sure, it was a bit disappointing, but it was also a chance to discuss the effects of atmospheric waves and how they might work above mountain ridges. And it was one more adventure story to share with others.

Chloe Morgan admits that she wasn't interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen. Her interest started by accident. Her younger brother was fascinated by dinosaurs, a common phase for kids, which she hadn't gone through. She helped him with a science project and found an article about new discoveries in Palaeontology. This article amazed her, and she realized she wanted to pursue this field. 

I asked her about the support she received because Palaeontology wasn't a typical career choice for young people then. She remembers meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous despite being young. She was nervous at first, worried he might find her annoying with her questions. However, he was patient and willing to listen, which made her feel comfortable.

I mentioned how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. Chloe thinks films like Jurassic Park have increased interest in dinosaurs but not necessarily in Palaeontology. She feels that palaeontologists in movies are often shown as either eccentric geniuses or awkward geeks, which isn't accurate. She explains that her job is varied, involving digging up dinosaur bones, working in labs, analyzing fossils, and writing for scientific publications. She also believes in communicating scientific findings to the public, especially to young people, to clear up misunderstandings about science and inspire them.

Chloe was involved in the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs, which aimed to show dinosaurs accurately. She says the program makers knew what they were doing, and she only needed to give advice occasionally. The dinosaurs in the show were very realistic, different from those in movies like Jurassic Park.

Chloe believes dinosaurs fascinate us because they appeal to our sense of exploration and discovery. They remind us that there is still much to learn about the world, and Palaeontology allows us to explore the past.

I'm going to say this once: when you're traveling by car with your family, even if you're six years old, you probably know you're not "there yet," even if you keep asking, "Are we there yet?" And when you do arrive, it's not "there" anymore; it's "here." So, if you think you might be "there," you should ask, "Are we here yet?" I'm sure no one wants to be "there" more than the parents who hear that question over and over during long car trips. 

Think about it. Wouldn't you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing to do? You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while the scenery passes by outside the window. In the front seat, mom or dad is there to give out juice boxes and cookies, change the radio station, and keep everything running smoothly. 

Are we there yet? I hope not. That is, until someone in the car does something annoying—like my younger brother, Tim, putting his foot on my side of the seat. I put my foot on his side, and soon we're fighting. The driver and co-pilot separate us, telling Tim to stay in his seat. This calms things down for a while, and the scenery continues to pass by. 

Later, I'm trying to read, and I feel a breeze on my arm. But the window isn't open. It's Tim, blowing air on me from his side. He's not touching me, so technically he's not doing anything wrong. But it makes me angry. Tim gets yelled at, and there's more swerving. Then things calm down again—for now. 

Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to deal with us in the back seat. When we ask, "Are we there yet?" he often says, "Yes, we're here. Get out of the car." "But Dad, we're still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour." "Oh, then maybe we're not there yet." That keeps us quiet for a while. 

You know you're finally "there" when the adults get out of the car and move far away from the kids who have bothered them for hours. So remember: if mom and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is no, you're not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope people will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains that they wanted to create a space where people can connect without using technology. She says, "Everyone is busy with their phones and gadgets. We wanted to bring people together in a way that doesn't involve screens. It's natural for people to be together and communicate."

The games played in their café are called 'Eurogames.' These games have gentle themes like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources, keeping everyone involved until the end. This idea was improved in 'co-operative' games, where players win or lose as a team, encouraging more social interaction. 

One popular Eurogame is Pandemic, created by North American designer Matt Leacock. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings. He remembers playing it with friends and feeling scared but excited. He wanted to create a game that made everyone feel good, whether they won or lost. 

Leacock loved board games since he was a child, even though he often felt disappointed by them. With help from his uncle, he started designing better games. Pandemic became very successful, and its follow-up version included more storytelling. Leacock explains that it is like an electronic game where you develop characters and the world changes, creating an unfolding story.

Interestingly, the growth of video games has helped the success of modern board games. Video games have made playing games more normal. Ben Hogg, who works for a games company, says, "Everyone with a smartphone has at least one game they like to play." 

In the past, video games allowed people to play together in the same room. But now, many video games are played online, where players are not physically together. This has led some people to look for games they can play with others in person. John and Zuzi's café shows that tabletop gaming is more than just fun. In our online world, these games offer a way to connect with others in real life, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced many big UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with many false starts. Jamie's mother was a great singer and taught him to play the guitar. Growing up, he only listened to a local radio station for middle-aged people, which influenced his music taste. He heard a modern song for the first time when he was 12. Around that age, he had to choose between playing tennis at a national level and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room playing the piano. Although he was good at tennis, he realized it wasn't what he wanted to do for the rest of his life because it was too much hard work. At 17, he left school to become a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as interested in a music career. Jamie told his parents he wanted to pursue music, explaining that he wrote lyrics during economics lessons and played the piano every day. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he signed with a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels only wanted him as a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend. Jamie eventually found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he switched to another label to release a new album, but fame and fortune didn't come. He felt he was often in the wrong place at the wrong time as an artist, but as a writer, he was in the right place. Writing for others became his strength. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK, helping new artists start their careers. Sometimes he explains to artists that aiming for the charts is not a bad thing. He asks them why they wouldn't want millions of people to listen to their music. He believes in writing songs that are both amazing and likely to sell well. Jamie is honest about wanting to write number-one hits, without arrogance. He knows he has a talent for it and focuses on writing the best music. When he works with someone in the studio, his goal is to create music that is globally successful and to write classic modern pop songs.

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very famous online but might be unknown to people who don't watch videos of bike stunts. He is a 'street trials cyclist,' which means he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to another. These stunts are filmed and shared online. 

When I met him at a BMX park, many local boys and even older people recognized him and called him a 'legend.' After seeing his skills, I agreed. I was surprised by his bravery and creativity. Before each stunt, he explained what he planned to do, and I often doubted he could do it. But he always succeeded. When I praised him, he seemed not very interested. Despite his online fame, Tony doesn't like being a celebrity. He finds it hard to interact socially and prefers doing things rather than talking about them. 

This is interesting because his fame comes from social media and camera technology. He admits that this technology helps him make a living, but he feels that people focus too much on screens. However, he is not complaining because he earns well from his videos, which would have been just a hobby in the past.

From my experience with top athletes, I know that two things are important to become a top competitor: energy and the ability to overcome disappointment. These are more important than talent and help someone keep going despite failures. In risky sports, mental strength is crucial. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times but got up and tried again until he succeeded.

Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some think he takes unnecessary risks. Tony says these people don't understand the sport and don't know that he gets expert advice to minimize risks. He is careful about the risks he takes. He believes it's important to be aware of dangers. He divides people into those who can't overcome fear and those who can. He feels fear but finds a way to get past it. He is not addicted to risk and spends a lot of time planning. He needs to be in the right mindset before trying a new stunt and knows he must stay calm before jumping. If he fully commits, he is fine.

Television presenter Helen Skelton has done many dangerous challenges for charity. She has run a marathon in the desert and traveled down the Amazon River in a small boat. Her latest challenge was walking on a high wire, which is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground. She walked between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist connected to another wire above her. To help her balance and not fall, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen learned from an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she found high-wire walking very different. "The training was a shock," Helen said. "I didn’t know how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, then an hour of exercises, and another hour after practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so I could continue if I slipped. Every time I fell, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!" On the day of the challenge, it was windy. Helen stayed calm by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. "That was the scariest thing I’ve done," she said afterward. "I’m glad it’s over!" Despite this, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by skiing, using a kite, and biking.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, which is an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. Before this, he had written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motor sports and worked on building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and even used it to travel to Amsterdam for a holiday. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a regular touring bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two failed attempts in 2001 and 2003, when he had to stop because of a knee injury, he finally started his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries on four continents. The best part of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘Even though I met cyclists who could ride up mountains, which I couldn’t do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further I traveled from home, the more amazed people were by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. He got a serious fever and was stuck in a hostel bed without medicine for ten long days. He had no money for hospital bills or to get back home. Despite all this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have started using a new tool called a 'night-vision scope' that helps us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we are not sure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We know a lot about what they do during the day, but not at night, because we didn't have the right equipment before. This new scope gives us clear pictures, even on nights without moonlight, so we can learn more and make better decisions about how to protect their habitat. The work is tough. There are four of us, and each of us works six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some areas and write down notes on every duck I see. The weather has been challenging – some nights are mild, but often it is wet. It is so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep, even for our special snow vehicles. Still, I enjoy the challenge, especially compared to what summer will bring – many hours in a lab, where we will look at our results together. It will be hard to be inside, but it is important to do this. And I wouldn't change it for anything!

Text: 'When I tell people about my job, they can hardly believe it exists. But it's true! I spend my workdays eating chocolate. Tasting chocolate is very important to make sure customers get perfect, high-quality chocolate bars from the company I work for. Every week, I get samples from our factory. These are small amounts of chocolate that I check for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit. I spend time choosing the best ones for the chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I make. I also give samples to my colleagues, which makes them happy! My kitchen is full of machines and ingredients to experiment with. It's great to have a private space to go to during the day. Every day is different in this job. Sometimes I'm at our food lab, and other times I'm traveling to buy raw materials. This can be hard because I have a young family. But I love the variety and the fact that there is no routine, although I think the best part is still the chocolate! People often ask if I get tired of chocolate. I've worked with it for a long time, and I've never felt like I didn't want to eat it. In fact, I often go home and eat more chocolate in the evening!'

Have you ever thought about what it's like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson is from Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. Her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which means flying through the air in front of an amazed audience. During the year-long course, students slowly take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, "For a circus career, performers need to avoid doing the same thing all the time. It's important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great part is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important—circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is important, but the best performers are those who want success, have imagination, and never stop improving their skills. People often think you might get injured or only work a short time each year. But the real issue is planning for the future because you can only perform while you're young, and then you need to think about other options." The course also teaches business planning. Many former students have started businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, however, that it's not a job for making a lot of money! "The work usually means not having a regular salary. It's also competitive—but a lot of fun!"

You might not know her name or recognize her face, but you've probably heard her voice many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. She supports the lead singer by singing in the background. Some people think backing singers aren't good enough to be lead singers, but that's not true. They often need to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry! 

"What I love about my job is that when I go into the recording studio, I never know what I'll be asked to sing," she says. "It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Or it might be a funny little tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I'm often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do the job!"

"Excellent musical skills are essential for my work, plus the ability to learn quickly. There's often no sheet music to look at. I'll never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, and an orchestra too. I was scared because if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are long enough already."

"One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers don't always know which musical range is best for the female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to improve it."

Julie Deane started her business with only basic knowledge of fashion. She created a successful company selling 'satchels,' which are traditional school bags. These bags are now sold in famous stores and are popular with celebrities. Before choosing to make satchels, Julie considered different business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning. She didn't just go with her first idea. When she decided on satchels, not everyone agreed with her choice. Julie says, "Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced." She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had never had a career but had a natural talent for business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children's storybooks. Although Julie didn't know much about fashion blogs, they played a big role in her success. At first, she sold about one satchel a week. To get more attention, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her satchels grew, as did the speed of production. Julie now enjoys seeing which celebrity is photographed with a satchel. While other companies spend money on online advertising, she uses the internet community to get ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a difficult time when another company copied her satchel design to sell similar products. Because of this, she now makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices, where people love to work. There is now a new factory, and while the building is important, it's the team that makes it a special place.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard to balance training with schoolwork. When they were teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started competing. Vicky thought it looked exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so she could easily attend training sessions after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. Then, at 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky said, ‘I loved winning competitions for years, but I started to feel tired of it all – and when the excitement stops, there’s no point. Luckily, I found a new career.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sport,’ she says. ‘The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, and it brings young people together as part of a larger group.’ The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky says, ‘Some people aren’t sure if having celebrities is always good for a charity. They think celebrities only do it to promote themselves, which can hide the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.’

Ana Ronson, a singer-songwriter, grew up in Ireland. Her parents weren't musicians, but there was always music at home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. Ana first sang in front of an audience at school, but she was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested she join the school theatre club to gain confidence. After some time in the club, she sang happily with 50 other students at a concert. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in just three days and enjoyed it so much that she joined a songwriting course taught by a professional. Even though she was the youngest, she knew more about music than many others. However, Ana felt the teacher didn't listen to her, so she wrote a song called Something to Say about her frustration. She posted it online, and it became very popular. People loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics each time they listened. Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled across Ireland to ask her to join Isotope. At first, Ana was unsure because she didn't know the company and didn't want to be told what to sing. But Joss convinced her this wouldn't happen, and soon she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and it was a fantastic evening. Ana prefers writing songs about difficult times because she feels there's more to express. One of her favorite songs is Decision, about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it affected him. While she hopes fans like her songs, her main goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on an amazing trip. I traveled by boat on a guided group tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He’s a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. He loves boats, but I don’t share that interest. However, I had always wanted to visit the area since I saw it on TV as a child. I knew our great-grandparents lived there before moving to Europe. So, I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally said yes!

A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we were going to visit. But luckily, the weather forecast for our trip was for calm seas. I was busy at work and didn’t have much time to think about what needed to be done. But Harry promised he’d taken care of everything, so I stopped worrying.

After arriving in Canada, we joined the group, packed our limited supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide mentioned that very few people lived along that coast. On the first morning, the only other living creatures we saw were dolphins and birds. There were islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far, so I just focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water.

We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches along the coast. They were full of amazing colored fish, many of which I didn’t recognize. It was great to stop worrying about how quickly or slowly the day was passing. We never forgot lunch or dinner, which we all made together over campfires. When we finally fell asleep on the boats each evening, even though the beds were hard, it really felt like stress-free living!

When it was time to leave, I was sad. How could I return to normal life again? But I knew if I stayed, I’d miss my family and friends. I was also looking forward to telling everyone at home about our adventures!

My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. When I was a kid, I went to watch many of his games. You might think that seeing so many games would make me love basketball, but it actually did the opposite. I liked telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I usually took a book to read instead of watching the games. 

When I started secondary school, I was not yet a teenager but was already two meters tall. Because of my height, my sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training session, but I thought I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. However, the teacher believed in me more than I did. After a few weeks, I agreed to play against another school. My parents came to watch, which made me nervous, but it turned out fine in the end!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did really well. I even joined an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn't enjoy being far from my parents at first. At home, I didn't have much time with friends because of training, so that part didn't change much. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly too!

I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I was too light for my height, so I had to work on that first. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it.

Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college, but I needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. After thinking about different options, I decided to train as a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. This job involved showing visitors around the city, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed it. I got to see my city through the eyes of tourists, and it felt new every time! After finishing my studies, I chose to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but I learned that to get a license as a full-time tour guide, I needed to know a lot more than I already did. In Chicago, guides must answer many questions about the city, including its architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging but interesting months, I got my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent tour guide. Being a tour guide is not just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group in crowds.
