By day 24, though, he says, he was living in bear world, at bear speed, with bear senses. 'We find a new hole and wait. We shuffle, hop, bend, stretch and run to stay warm. Five hours of watching and then with no warning at all I catch a glimpse so brief that I almost miss it. But the camera's locked on the hole on full zoom and my eye's very quickly on the viewfinder. Nothing for a couple of seconds and then an unmistakable black nose. Nose becomes muzzle, grows bigger to become full head and in less than a minute she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow in front of the hole. She's looking at me but she's not bothered. I've just pulled out of a close-up thinking this can't get much better … when she sets off on a long slide down the slope. I'd swear it's partly in sheer pleasure,' he recounts, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. 'Clearly it's their first view of the world … It's show time on the slopes and we have front-row seats.' Now Allan would like to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and experience the impact of it first hand. He says he would be able to make an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting more supplies on the way. He had to swim through very cold water and deal with frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole too. Now, he is back in the Arctic, getting ready for an even bigger expedition. Explorers are confident and determined people, and they need to be. This time, there is more at risk. Pen and two colleagues will go on a three-month, 1,000-kilometer journey to the North Pole, measuring the thickness and density of the ice. No one has done this before, and the results will be very important for scientists. This will give the clearest picture yet of how global warming is affecting the ice in the polar region. Pen was trained for this kind of work. As a child, he was looked after by a woman who had worked for the famous explorer Scott of the Antarctic. She was hired to make him tough by sending him out into the cold Scottish mountains with very few clothes. His father also loved adventures in the cold, and Pen had unusual physical strength. Pen is married to Mary, who loves the outdoors too. She helps run his polar guide business and says she worries more about him when he is at home because he is often thinking about the Arctic. For fun, she once raced against him in a mountain event where riders on horses compete against people on foot. Mary and her horse finished an hour before Pen. Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. Pen says it is harder to leave them this time. When he last went, his children were one and five years old. He made a mistake by telling his son, "You’re the man of the house now, look after your mum and your sister." His son took it very seriously, which was too much pressure. Because of this, Pen plans to have little contact with them while in the Arctic. "If you call them, you remind them how far away you are," he says. He is spending his last days before leaving getting his equipment ready. "Out on the ice, you can’t fix things easily," he explains. Ann Daniels, a top polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer, will join him. A team of six will fly in supplies to support them. Being part of a team is more stressful for Pen, and he is also worried about his age. "I’m going to be 47 on Thursday. I haven’t trained as much as I’d like," he says. Why? "Organizing things always seems more urgent. So I’m almost afraid of what I’m going to ask of myself." Pen believes his mission connects exploration with the search for knowledge, like past explorers. "Reaching the North Pole was a personal goal," he admits, "and not very useful to others. This time, scientists will benefit from the data, and we’re trying to involve as many people as possible in what’s happening in the Arctic Ocean. This is important work, and only we can do it," he says. "Our skills, which seemed strange and not useful before, are now very important. Suddenly, we’re useful to society again."

I took a year off and wondered what to do next. Being an Olympian is amazing, and I had opportunities to write, work on TV, and speak at schools and businesses. But I missed having a competitive goal. I wanted to stay fit in case I decided to try for the Olympics again, so I entered marathons and triathlons. That was good, but I kept thinking about TV presenter Ben Fogle's invitation: "Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?" I love rowing and missed it, but I wasn't ready for intense training. I talked to some rowing friends about the race, but they weren't interested. I knew if I joined, I would want to win. I wasn't sure if Ben was the best partner for winning, but being an underdog sounded fun. 

Ben was already planning to race and had managed to gather the entry fee and deposit for a boat, making the race a real possibility. We discussed the costs, which were high, with the boat and equipment alone costing £70,000. We thought we had a good chance, but it would take effort to secure everything. I also had to consider the loss of income from being away, as speaking at business events is a good way to earn money after retiring from sports. It's nice that people are interested, but I prefer having a new goal to talk about. Rowing across the Atlantic would give me something new to share.

Planning this adventure taught me to appreciate the simpler life of a full-time athlete. Preparing for the Olympics was tough, but everything was organized with doctors and dieticians. I worried about how people would see me racing with a TV presenter, thinking it might look like I just wanted to be on TV. But during our preparations, those worries faded. The Atlantic Rowing Race is more about mental strength than just rowing. Ben had done tough challenges like the Marathon des Sables and spent time at sea and on a deserted island. However, he couldn't row well. I was surprised by his lack of skill, and he was surprised by my lack of patience. I could have been more patient, but I needed to be honest about the improvements he needed. I should have expected his level when I agreed to race with him.

Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle, in the far north of Finland. At 26, I felt restless. I dreamed of Arctic landscapes, cold and empty spaces, maybe because of the noise and crowded life in London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They agreed to hire me as a husky dog handler for a busy winter season. From December to February, they take tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow, for trips lasting from an hour to five days. They started with six dogs, which quickly grew to more than 100. Recently, they took over a second place called the 'wilderness farm', which they said was a beautiful but simple place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months if I knew what I was getting into. 'The hours are long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical.’ I started packing right away.

November 6, London On my flight, I look at a page with more than 100 pictures of huskies. I am supposed to memorize their names before I arrive, but I feel distracted and nervous. I put the page down and look out the window instead. People say that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, like a wave of flowers and leaves opening. But I think I am seeing the opposite, with winter moving south and the rivers freezing.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta The bus north is everything I hoped for. We drive through endless dark forests with thin conifers covered in snow, stopping sometimes to let reindeer move out of the way. I arrive at the farm after dark and am barely inside when I’m given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. 'Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?’ Anna asks. It’s a rhetorical question. I follow the barking, which becomes very loud by the time I reach the dog sheds. Three people are running back and forth, pulling out huskies and harnessing them to sleds. The dogs are almost crazy with excitement, pulling hard on the ropes to start running. I can barely hear to introduce myself, but the others are too busy to talk much anyway. I stand on the side and pet one of the quieter dogs. Someone gestures at me impatiently – 'Get in!’ – and I almost fall into the nearest sled. A command is given, and with a jerk, we are off into the dark, with only a head torch for light.

November 15, Hetta It doesn’t take long to become part of the husky guides, but first, I face tough questions about what I bring to the group. 'Are you useful?’ Anna asks. I’m unsure. Am I? More questions show that no, I am not: I have never driven a snowmobile, haven’t done woodwork since school, and have never chopped anything with an axe. 'You do have a driving licence?’ someone asks finally. I nod, relieved. The basics of dog-sledding can be learned quickly: lean into the corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and, whatever happens, don’t let go of the handlebar. But everything else seems very complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and watering the dogs become very difficult in freezing conditions. A bowl of water will freeze solid while you watch, so we must make a 'soup’ of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head is spinning with instructions, and my muscles ache from dragging heavy sleds – and from being dragged around by overexcited huskies. But I feel triumphant. 'I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw,’ I email friends. 'In the snow.’

On that day, when Radcliffe crossed the finish line, the press gathered to understand her amazing run. Her time was so good that it would qualify her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Journalists were curious about a natural treatment she used, emu oil, which Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had recommended. Radcliffe used it to heal after a training accident where she ran into a bike. Radcliffe says the achievement didn't really sink in at the time. She felt it was just what she was meant to do that day. Her team had a motto: no limits.

During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio. Her physiotherapist, Gerard Hartmann, was also there. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried if she could keep up the fast pace, fearing she might drop out. Hartmann was upset by this, but he understood why someone might think it was risky to start so fast if they didn't know how fit she was.

With 800 meters left, Radcliffe realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she ran the last part in less than three minutes. She had already run 41 kilometers very fast but still managed to sprint the last distance in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run quicker than that." The race director, Dave Bedford, said he didn't expect anyone to come close to that time soon. Radcliffe thought she would return and do it again next year, but unfortunately, that didn't happen.

After the race, people wondered how Radcliffe, with her awkward running style, beat the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with her for weeks, helping her manage the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said, "I've worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one could handle that level of pain like her." Hartmann would travel 13 hours from Ireland to her training base in France, and as soon as he arrived, Radcliffe was ready for a two-hour session. She pushed him to give his best, which made her so good.

During that time, Hartmann spent so much time with Radcliffe that other athletes became resentful. Radcliffe herself can't fully explain why no one has beaten her record. She trained very hard, but she believes there are more talented people out there. She thought Mary Keitany might break her record. Radcliffe thinks maybe people are racing each other more than pushing themselves to their limits. She always pushed herself hard, even when she was winning.

Radcliffe didn't know it then, but that marathon was the peak of her career. She never ran as fast again, but she inspired many women to start long-distance running.

When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I didn't know how people would react. At that time, there was a lot of talk about a food 'revolution' happening in Britain. I believed our show added something new to this movement, but I was still worried. Would people like a cooking show that included not just techniques, but also history, nostalgia, and science? I watched the first episode feeling both happy and scared. I didn't need to worry. The show was successful and led to many other interesting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. Each project feels like a journey, whether it's exploring the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I then wrote several books in a series called 'Perfection', each with its own TV show. In these, the journey was often very physical, involving travel with passports and suitcases. In Search of Total Perfection is the latest in the series. In it, you travel around the world to meet amazing people, like a man who makes a special golden pasta. These people have spent years trying to achieve their own idea of perfection. Perfection is very personal. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was difficult, and I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish was left out. But after a long meeting, the TV team and I came up with a list that had something for everyone. This showed me that everyone has their own idea of what perfection is, based on their emotions, memories, and surroundings. I knew from the start that I wasn't claiming the recipes were 'perfect'. But I thought that by using my skills and knowledge, and by talking to food experts, I could find out what made these dishes special. The dictionary says 'perfection' means being perfect, but it also means improving through constant experimentation. Trying new ideas and changing them until you have something unique. The TV series allowed me to explore foods, people, and places I hadn't seen before, and I was excited about that. Searching for the best ingredients took me around the world. Some of my adventures included visiting a canning factory that processed the wrong type of tomato and a dairy farm with low standards where we couldn't film. To perfect each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow to make ice cream, cooking chicken in a hospital scanner, and almost burning my house down trying to make a Neapolitan-style pizza.

We were still a few hours away from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise and suddenly went off the road into a field, stopping completely. John got out and looked under the hood of the van. He stood there for a long time, looking at the engine with his hands in his pockets, pretending to know what he was doing. Finally, he admitted, "Actually, I have no idea what I'm doing," and he and Mum started laughing. Bea was worried and said, "We can't stay here forever." The field was large, with just grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. I agreed with Bea, saying, "No, we can't stay here forever," because it was always safe to agree with her. We both got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John walk away to find someone who knew about cars. Mum lay down on the grass and asked me to tell a story. Bea lay next to her and encouraged me to tell one. So, I told them about how, the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I shared everything the birds talked about, like breadcrumbs, other birds, and the weather. I even told them about the birds arguing over a worm. Bea said, "That's silly, no one understands bird language." My eyes felt like they were burning. "I do," I said, but I didn't sound convincing. "Liar," Bea said. I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered every word? The more I thought about it, the less sure I was. "Mum...?" But she had fallen asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to a hotel. Bea didn't want to get out, but the boys didn't mind. They waved and smiled at her through the back door windows. We followed John into a café near the road where our van was parked. "It's a hotel," John whispered. "It might be expensive." "We'll just have some tea," Mum said, and we sat in the shade on the terrace. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot and said, "It's like syrup in there." We stayed at the café all day while John tried to fix the engine. "It's a miracle it got us this far," he said as it got dark. Mum made beds for us with blankets in the hotel garden. It was nice to sleep on ground that wasn't moving. "I'll have to get us towed into Marrakech," John said. Later, we were in a truck watching our van being towed with John driving it. At first, Bea didn't want to move, so John carried her into the truck. She sat in the front with the driver. I kept wondering how we would get home since our van needed to be towed everywhere. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I fell asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom. She was talking to two other pianists who were playing at the Prague Classical Music Festival. They were not competing like Lucy. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city, but Lucy didn't catch her name because of the noise. It was something like Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke English well enough to discuss the music they were playing and their travel plans.

Lucy mentioned she might go to the Tanglewood festival that summer. It sounded impressive, but she didn't really want to go. She often did things like concerts and competitions that took her around the world, making her miss so much school that she wasn't officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she studied with tutors from the University of San Francisco. She hadn't even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists in her age group from around the world. Out of thousands of applicants, she was chosen. Her dad bought her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to celebrate, and her little brother Gus dreamed of being at the festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. But Lucy hadn't applied herself; her mom did it for her. Her mom said she didn't want Lucy to be disappointed if she didn't get in. Lucy thought it was more about not giving her the chance to say no. At that time, Lucy thought causing trouble was the worst thing to do, so she didn't try to back out.

The guy from Tokyo seemed surprised when Lucy mentioned Tanglewood. He asked her age, and she said she was fifteen. He and Liesel/Louisa exchanged a look, and Liesel/Louisa said, "Wow." Lucy didn't mean to brag. It was hard to know when sharing her achievements was too much. Liesel/Louisa then excused herself to talk to someone else. The guy from Tokyo stayed and asked if Lucy had ever been to Japan. He had long, shaggy hair, like many male musicians, to show they were cool. Lucy said she had been to Japan once when she was eight. Before he could reply, Lucy's grandfather came over and took her away to introduce her to someone. He told her not to get too friendly with the competition. Lucy said they weren't the competition, but her grandfather insisted everyone was.

Her grandfather took her around the room to talk to important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, only catching about half of what was said. In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather told her she did well and that he was proud of her. He said the festival was important and that people were talking about her. Lucy liked being somebody, even if it made some people jealous or think she was too young for the attention. Being a concert pianist didn't make her special to the kids she used to go to school with. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn't know or care that she could play a Rachmaninov allegro well. But in places like the festival, she knew she mattered.

"Dad said, 'Spending too much time online isn't good for you. You need to experience the real world.' It's hard to argue with him, so I looked into what experts say about it, and it's quite interesting. Research shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a strong sense of who they are, and are learning important technical skills for the digital age. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says social networking is a key part of growing up today. Teenagers don't just use media for tasks like buying tickets or checking emails like adults do; they live in it. It's not about whether it's good or bad, but how you use it that matters.

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did at our age? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it's like the modern version of hanging out at a youth club, where today's parents used to go to share jokes and gossip. It helps teenagers develop their identity away from their parents and learn to deal with teenage issues and interact with their peers.

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says adolescence is a time to ask, 'Who am I?' Social networking can help you find your identity by letting you share your favorite music or sports, discover what you like, and see that others have different views. Research shows that active social networkers are less self-centered than those who don't use social media. He also says that social media can be helpful if you're shy because communicating online can be easier than face-to-face, allowing you to practice social skills in a less intimidating way.

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can help quiet people with specific interests connect with others who share those interests. For example, if only a few people at your school like a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a group online with similar interests, you can feel popular in a different way.

Pauline White, a digital education expert, says teenagers who find new interests online, join groups of like-minded people, and create their own content are really using social networks well. She thinks social networking is becoming a creative force, with teenagers making videos, podcasts, and blogs about their interests. Photo-sharing sites are changing creativity, allowing photographers to connect, learn, and share images, which can help in the workplace. Every business uses social media to sell and build brand awareness, so understanding how it works is important. For example, if you create a product and have 1,000 friends on social networks, they could be potential customers. Linking these networks can create a customer base.

Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they start working, agrees Matthews. Many sites offer the chance to collaborate with others to create and share content. Collaboration is a key skill for the 21st century and important for being employable in a digital age."

When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, they probably don't imagine a long trip through nine western states in the US and a Canadian province. However, my parents had a different idea for our summer vacation this year. My dad decided to plan what many teenagers would consider a nightmare: a big family bonding trip. Before the trip, my parents kept saying, "Not enough people do this anymore," while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, "There's probably a good reason for that!"

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and all kinds of clothes to prepare for any weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. With barely enough space left in the car, we started our "Family Great American Road Trip." As we left our comfortable home for smaller accommodations over the next five thousand miles, I wasn't the only one wondering what we were getting into.

We headed west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had some adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under the darkest, star-filled skies, but only after almost being blown off the highway by a dust storm. We quickly learned that on the road, cattle have the right-of-way!

The next day, we were up early and on the move again. I noticed a pattern forming. The desert turned into mountains. The days started to blend together, but each adventure was unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and moved on to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that friendly tourist town gave us a hint of what we would experience later. As we climbed to our next destination, we learned that roads marked for Jeeps are best left to Jeep drivers. Everywhere we stopped, we saw a mix of ancient and modern. Dodging construction traffic became normal. We laughed as we posed by the big "CLOSED" signs at the Four Corners Monument.

We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. "Bear jams," where traffic stops to let a bear cross, were common, and our own close encounter with a bear and a worried park ranger gave us unforgettable memories. As we continued, life back home seemed far away, and even the old hotel we stayed in, with its creaky floors and no internet or cell phone service, couldn't dampen our spirits. In exchange, I got to see the most amazing views I've ever seen.

After watching a rainstorm from our cozy hotel in Canada, my family and I headed back south. My parents were right. You don't need to go to an exotic foreign place to find something amazing. It was both happy and sad to be home again, but at least I hadn't fought with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos of our crazy journey to look through and remember. For me, the best memories were the unplanned and spontaneous moments.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years because her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy would finish her last year of school, living under the care of the college Head. It was important for Amy to stay because it was her final year, and she was happy to have the best room at the college, with a kitchen and study area. She also had free Internet and phone access. Jeff and Dahlia would still keep an eye on Amy.

Rose was moving to her grandmother's house. She only had vague holiday memories of her grandmother and had never met her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, Rose's parents were not very excited, but Daisy insisted it was no trouble and wanted to reconnect with her granddaughter. Rose didn't fully understand why her parents didn't get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past. Rose was ten years old the last time she saw her grandmother, but she had happy memories.

Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and liked bringing people together. Rose expected to receive dinner invitations, coffee morning requests, and shopping trips soon. Her grandmother was not a typical old lady and seemed to attend more social events than the Queen of England. Before moving, Dahlia and Rose talked. Rose was mature and knew about healthy living. She wanted independence, like playing music loudly, inviting friends over, or going out without always asking for permission. She didn't want to be nagged about homework or staying out late.

Daisy understood, and Dahlia gave Rose a new touch-screen mobile phone for emergencies. Rose was very happy. They agreed to trust each other: Daisy would trust Rose to act maturely, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If there were any problems, they would talk about it. Rose was not a wild child, and her school friends were similar, so her school reports and exam results were always good. This helped her. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and start her life again. It was her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. She knew this would be the last time because she was starting her final two years at school. For Rose, it was a new beginning, a new piece in the puzzle of her life.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first to suggest she might write a novel. She thought writing a book would be a great achievement because it seemed challenging, unlike other activities teenagers might do, like competing in the Olympics. When she turned 13, she decided to try writing a novel. Now, that novel is about to be published. Charlotte recently told her former teacher, who was surprised because she thought Charlotte would write a book at 30 or 40. Charlotte didn't see why she should wait to do something she might be good at.

On a winter afternoon at her publisher's office, I met Charlotte, a 15-year-old girl who has written a book. The book is impressive: the story is confident and full of action. Except for the age of the main character, nothing suggests it was written by a teenager. A public relations representative is with us in case Charlotte needs support, but she is independent and confident, with a lively intelligence and a steady demeanor that keeps her from being overconfident.

Charlotte admits she is young and doesn't have all the answers. When asked about the complex moral issues in her book, she says, "I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t think my understanding of the world is limited by my age, but I’m not particularly wise either. I was just interested in exploring the theme of taking responsibility."

She has a theory about how teenagers are portrayed in books. She believes there are three types: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the awkward teenager who lacks social skills. She found these stereotypes frustrating. "What if you’re basically fine? There aren’t many stories about characters who aren’t inadequate in some way. Some writers unintentionally suggest that teenagers can’t know who they are because they lack experience, which can hurt their self-confidence."

Charlotte has always loved reading famous fantasy writers, but they almost discouraged her from writing. "Books by my favorite fantasy writers explore deep things about psychology and life. I wondered if I needed to do the same to write a good book and if I was capable of it." However, she praises a book called How Not to Write a Novel, which advises that if the reader can guess what happens next, the suspense is lost.

Some might think Charlotte's parents, both journalists, helped her get published. Her father's connection in publishing did help get her book read initially. She acknowledges her luck, as getting a first novel read is difficult, regardless of the author's age. "Every aspiring writer needs support and a lucky break, but after that, you’re on your own. Writers succeed or fail based on their talents, so I don’t take things for granted," Charlotte concludes.

Text: "‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then one guy, David, who had some experience in freestyle ski-jumping and wanted to show he knew what he was doing, went first. He skied down the slope towards the jump. He hit the ramp fast and flew up, arms flailing. Even we could see something was wrong. We held our breath. He hit the ground, lost both skis, and flipped head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth kindly told us, ‘speed is unpredictable.’ Maybe I wasn’t meant for this freestyle stuff. On past skiing holidays, I liked practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers doing tricks on ramps and half pipes in skateboard parks. I thought it looked fun, but I didn’t know how, and I was afraid of being laughed at. Then my parents decided we’d have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a big indoor facility near the slopes, with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow. Students jumped, tried new tricks, and landed in foam pits – not a real introduction to what was ahead on the slopes. After practicing indoors, students went outside to try for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan said. ‘Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just throw themselves down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – once you’re on the real jumps, if you hit the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat section behind the jump before the slope steepens again to become the landing zone. Land in the zone and you keep moving forward, minimizing impact. Land on the flat and you stop suddenly, which is painful. That’s why you need speed. At first, it was hard to convince my body to ignore my brain and race towards the jump. My legs would almost go backward as I neared the launch point, so I came down hard on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt shorter. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines in the center. I thought I’d hate being indoors, looking at the snowy peaks outside, but bouncing on the trampolines was addictive. Some drills copied moves we’d make while ski-jumping, others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body was doing as you spun in the air. Gareth gave us feedback. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed work – every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before take-off, and then I was in the foam cubes next to the trampoline. We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more setbacks before I finally landed properly. Gareth seemed as happy as I was, and for a few moments, I felt proud of achieving such a difficult goal. But that didn’t last long. On the final run of the day, I forced myself not to slow down as I approached the jump, became airborne, and landed correctly in the landing zone. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer attached to my feet."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you grip the safety harness tightly. The ride stops for a moment, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly climbs up. There is a pause, then a sudden drop, and you feel your stomach lift. You speed forward, turn sharply left, and go upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you scream from deep inside. But you chose to be here, like millions of others who visit theme parks every year.

Amusement parks are a big business, attracting people with exciting rides. Behind these rides are large teams of creative engineers and designers. Being a 'rollercoaster designer' might sound like a child's dream job, but it is a real and challenging career. Designers must create rides that are both thrilling and safe, while also offering something new to keep visitors interested.

Many people think rollercoasters have become more intense over time, but most of the techniques used today were invented by John Miller, a US designer, in the early 20th century. Back then, rollercoasters were more extreme, but now designers must work within the limits set by ride manufacturers.

I talked to three rollercoaster experts. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer,' said the skill is in putting the pieces together. Dr. John Roberts, an engineering expert, explained that it's about quickly changing directions to make people feel excited but safe. The goal is to create a ride that tells a story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, with features like the tallest ride or the most twists.

Professor Walker said that in the end, experience and testing are key. Jeff Hornick, a theme park development director, agreed that designers need to understand what passengers want and test the rides themselves. I asked if new technology like virtual reality will change rollercoaster design. Walker said that while technology can add to the experience, the physical ride will always be the main attraction.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already done a lot as a choreographer, creating dances for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances sometimes. I wonder why she does both activities with her busy schedule. She says, ‘Dancing again reminds me of what it feels like to be in the studio, taking orders from demanding choreographers, and how tense and frustrating that can be. Choreographers can forget what it’s like to rehearse all day long.’ As a choreographer, she enjoys teaching young students. ‘A new dancer is often open to exploring new ideas. In some ways, working with students is easier than with professionals because they’re willing to take risks. They want success, but they don’t yet know their strengths and weaknesses. This means they accept even harsh criticism. They might still question me sometimes, but I welcome their honest feedback.’

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. ‘There might be music I don’t like, but I still create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a composer’s music, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I can’t just choose a new piece. I’d like to be more experimental and switch to different pieces – it’d help lift the mood when rehearsals are tough. But I’m always working on big productions where the music is already decided by the composer and can’t be changed.’

Miranda doesn’t want to work with just one institution. ‘I think it’s important to keep meeting new people. But I have to remember that all the theatres and schools I work with have different methods and styles. So I have to adapt each time I go somewhere new, instead of doing the same thing. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.’

We talk about a recent documentary on ballet dancers and choreographers. ‘There have been glamorous documentaries before that were misleading,’ says Miranda. ‘This one tries to show viewers what life is really like in a dance company. There was a scene where a young dancer gets many corrections, and I smiled because I recognized it. She knows she’s not getting it right but can’t make her body do what’s needed. It’s hard to watch but not made up for the cameras. The public underestimates the work and dedication involved in ballet.’

I ask what makes a great ballet or dance production for Miranda. ‘It’s when everything – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers – comes together. Perfection might be too much to ask for, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can make up for a few wrong artistic choices. I’ve been in productions where the dance steps are great, but something about the costumes or props distracts. That’s disappointing.’

Miranda has done many different works, so I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? ‘People want to label you, and I don’t understand that. There’s also a trend to focus on one narrow area. I don’t follow that, though maybe one day I’ll be known for doing one thing. For now, I want to explore more.’

A friend once asked me why I travel when I can watch everything on TV. I agreed that TV shows amazing things, but why stay at home when there is so much to experience outside? This conversation gave me the idea for a crazy four-day trip and a film to encourage people to turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the main part of the film. I attached three wheels and some cables to it and used old seatbelts to secure myself. I put my luggage on the seats and slept on the sofa each night, even one night on the beach. Several friends joined me during the trip, helping to pull the sofa and motivating me to continue. I have been on several walking trips in recent years, but this was something completely new. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and it was on main roads. This meant I could stop at a roadside café and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino, instead of having the wind blow away my sandwiches while sitting on a rock. I often told people, "No, I'm not doing it for charity, and I'm not training for a marathon." When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to explain how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England rather than talk about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.

When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I was excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I usually traveled with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be good for me. At the Greek port, the man seemed curious when I asked for a single ferry ticket because the islands are popular with families. I explained that I wouldn't be alone for long; I would be joining ten others to swim around the tiny islands. Although he still looked puzzled, he let me on board with a smile. Our group had exchanged emails before we started, but there was little time to talk before our first group swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would be with us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, then it was time for our first proper 1.5 km swim, and I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but never long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I was at the back of the slow group - not where I wanted to be. I watched faster swimmers moving ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first distance, though, and was happy when I finally did it on my own. The following days had a routine: jumping in, reaching a comfortable speed, and stopping to admire the scenery. As the swims got longer, my speed and enjoyment increased. There seemed little need for the support boat. I can hardly wait to come again next year.

Being a flight attendant isn't easy, but it's a great job for a young person like me. Since I started, I've traveled to many places, like the US and Australia. I work with amazing people, have a lot of free time, and life is never boring. As a child, I went to a boarding school abroad, so I often flew alone. I felt lonely and would ask flight attendants if I could help give out meals, and some let me. This experience stayed with me when I wanted to leave my banking job and find a new career. At the interview, there were many young people, and many were accepted. They were often well-qualified and changing careers, like me. I practiced what to say before the interview, focusing on my strengths and work experience, not just my love for travel. I got the job! I recommend this work to anyone because there are many benefits, but free flights aren't the main one. Airline staff work very hard, and there's a saying: "no-one's finished till everyone's finished." It's like a big family. Even if we don't see each other often, we're still close. When I'm not working, I don't have to take work home. If I have difficult passengers, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won't see them again.

At the summer camp where I work, I love seeing the children succeed at things they didn't think they could do. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for many of them. Some children feel very nervous, but with some encouragement, they agree to try, and they all reach the top in the end. This makes them feel really good. At the start of the week, some children miss home. Surprisingly, it's not the very young ones who feel this way the most; it's usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We don't let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can call home after lunch. Then, when they ask again after dinner, we say it's a bit late to call now, do it tomorrow. Most children are fine after a couple of days, and by the end of the week, they thank us because they had a great time. It's not always the children who feel lonely. Sometimes, parents call a lot to ask how their child is doing, which isn't really necessary. Often, their child is busy playing games or doing something else, so we have to tell the parents to call back later. We often see a certain type of child come to camp, usually wearing expensive new clothes. These children usually argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why.

"Rock the Planet" is a musical show where the actors also need to be great musicians. It started in London last year after being in the USA for five years, where it won the 'Best Musical' award four times. However, using an all-British cast was challenging because the UK has stricter rules about how many shows young actors can do each week. In the USA, they can do more shows. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they have just won their first 'Best Musical' award. The London theatre is bigger than the one in the USA, but it has been full every night because everyone wants to hear the songs that were first popular in America.

I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, "It's amazing that I get paid to play, especially on a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar." He explained how busy the young actors are. "We have regular school lessons at the theatre every day. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends." I asked what his friends think of the show. "My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it's expensive for them," he said.

When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found an extra one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called "Days," which I didn't know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I was happy when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie's talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show's director wasn't there to hear my mistakes!

The young actors were already musicians, and some played several instruments, but none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie said the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were concentrating so much that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it's definitely worth seeing.
